text:
Hey, everyone. I'm Rudy. And I'm Wale. And in this episode of 'IoT All the Things'
its all about Automotive.

We're going to do
Connected Mobility solutions, machine learning
at the edge, Kinesis video,
and all things data lakes and analytics. And Rudy, what else is coming?

Well, don't forget to stay tuned
for our 'IoT All the Tricks' section, where we'll be talking
about the IoT Jumpstart.

So everyone,
get ready for 'IoT All the Things.' 'IoT All the Things.'

We have Dean Phillips
joining us from Automotive.

So Dean's going to dive into a whole
bunch of really cool use cases on the tech. So I'm super excited--
super excited about that.
Hi, guys. I'm Dean Phillips. I'm Worldwide Tech Lead for Automotive. I'm based in the Detroit area.

So good to be on. I think it's awesome to have you on because as we think
about all the kind of hot topics,

you know, especially
in IoT, as we get to scale, their customers are looking for things like 'how do you reduce cost in terms of IoT?'

So we've launched things
like IoT jobs, and some repricing, and allowing you to
kind of do updates at scale.

But I think what's really cool
about the automotive space is that you're probably seeing all these
kind of trends come up over and over again

in connected mobility architectures
and in vehicle architectures. So it's just great to dive in with you

and just really get a sense of
how this landscape is evolving. Yeah, I'm looking forward to it.

You know we can talk a little bit about
intelligent edge architectures we're seeing, customers implement in their vehicles,
next gen Connected Mobility Solutions. Maybe we'll talk about our new solution

that we're going to be
releasing shortly to enable all of that. Also, talk about the
importance of deep updates
for over-the-year updates in software, and even some stuff around data lakes.

So lots of cool stuff
we can get into today. Sweet. I'd love to dive into that first
one with connected mobility architectures.

What is that, right? For people who are coming in,
they're like, connected mobility? I thought it was just vehicles.

I thought we were just going
to be sitting there looking at Elon Musk or a Rocket, a Tesla truck. But, like, what is that really?

Well, you know, I've joked
with the guys a lot, saying, we're going to need
that third access to the maps

so we can deal with the
flying, you know, cars eventually.

But the fact is that we've
got a lot of our customers building micro-mobility solutions.

So you think about scooters
and the different things you can hop on on the streets to get around.

So it's not always just a vehicle. It's a lot of intelligent use cases
supporting a smarter city,

connecting all the things,
as you like to say. So traffic light, roadside units.

You name it. It's pretty interesting. So it's not just all about the car. And you think about the
importance of software to automotive.

Vehicles have 150 million
lines of code in them today.

And that's just increasing. And so something
like a scooter, for example,

when you have a bug
or it doesn't work properly, the only way to fix it is to shoot down
a new bundle of software to that thing.

So hopefully, we'll get in today
and we'll show you a little bit about how the Connected Mobility
Solution can enable that for customers

and point out just the state in automotive. Last year, I think there were
85 software-related recalls

across all the automotive industry. And then this year, we've already
had in the first quarter about 12,

I think, were reported by NHTSA, which is the National
Highway Safety and Traffic Association.

So if you think about all of that, there is a lot of complexity. So we're trying to help customers
enable those new solutions in their cars.

I think it's really interesting, Dean. You touched on something that is like-- you know, when I brought my car in, it was
basically like a software update, right?

So they came in like,
we're just going to apply a patch to help fix maybe how precision was done

or how they understand tire pressure. How is that kind of edge
architecture and then updates?

You mentioned this
is so much more software. How is that managed? What are some of the things
you're seeing from your customers?

Well, it's a number of things. I talked about the increase in the
amount of software going into vehicles.

And you think about all the
connectivity solutions we have today, where you can unlock
your doors or start your car.

You can preset the cabin
temperature in your vehicle. And that requires
a lot of IoT connectivity.

And the complexity
there just keeps increasing. So a lot of the cars--
you know, we've been doing this for
a number of years, right, a decade plus-- but we've solved the basic connectivity.

And now we're really focused
on enabling the more advanced use cases. so being able to dynamically
change the amount of data

coming from a vehicle, kind of like
you look at a CloudWatch Log,

and you can go
from standard to get the level, but where you're sending much
more data more frequently.

And you want to do that
for a short period of time so you can do the diagnostics and
the analytics to figure out what's wrong.

And so having an architecture
in the car that can support that is something that everybody's
rushing to implement today.

You mentioned a really cool part
of that is actually all the data you get. Because part of it is the idea
that you need to be able to

pull information off of sensors. But a larger part is how do
you actually implement a data lake?

How do you take all
these disparate sensors, turn it into something
that relates to a car,

and then look at trends over time? So how is that data lake, data
processing being done in the automotive space?

Yeah, that's a great topic. I mean, we're seeing
data lakes being spun up across the board with our customers.

BMW is a great example,
where they talk about how they've taken
the data from all their vehicles

and all their different
locations around the world, and they've created
this Cloud Data Hub, they call it.

And they've been able
to capture all this data centrally and enable the lines
of business across the company

to identify new business
opportunities and challenges.

And actually freeing it for analysis, so you can make new
features, like adaptive seat heaters,

that turn on and off
automatically without a user being engaged, or
being involved in that decision.

So those are just some of the things
that they can start to enable with machine learning and analytics
from the data they've captured.

If you're thinking about
how data lakes come together, it is kind of a mix of AWS services.
So you've got things like S3, right? All of our storage. And I always joke,

if you ever have to take
an AWS Solution Architect exam, the trick I got was 'All roads lead to S3.'

Yeah, just pick S3 as
the answer and you're good. I've passed all mine so far.

You know, Redshift's another one, and we see that
involved in these data lakes. Obviously, you've got to move data
around from one repository to another,

transform it so if things like Glue-- we see a lot of that. Of course, EMR, Elastic MapReduce,
for the Haduk workload.

So a lot of these technologies
people are kind of putting together today and addressing that
analysis zone, if you will,

on the data they've captured. Yeah, that's awesome.
And I think some of the other services I've seen used for
some of the in-flight processing

is you have IoT Analytics,
which is a service that lets you do some filtering enrichment
of data on the fly.

But then also Kinesis Analytics,
Kinesis Streams, Kinesis Firehose. You have lots of tools
in your proverbial tool belt

to figure out how to get your data
in the right format for your data lake. Absolutely. One of the use cases
we released a couple of years ago

in our Connected Vehicle Solution, was an example of a
streaming analytics application

to do anomaly detection on data
captured coming from the vehicle. So what we did-- if you think
about Kinesis Data Streams and Firehose--
the data comes in in little messages. And so with Kinesis Data Analytics,

we write a SQL-like application
where you can 'select star from topic y,
where data value equals x.'

And then you can
start to do some selection and processing of those
messages in real time.

And so the example we 
did using a random conforus, was identify anomalies on oil temperature.

That was just the
one example we implemented. But you can see how
you can combine a number of

different data values
and messages from different topics and figure out, OK, this
is the analytics app I want to build.

And so you can use
that pattern, that example, as the foundation for your solution.

People are interesting too, though. We're starting to see more
Object Detection at the edge.

So eventually, it could land in S3. But Dean, you're seeing this use case,
where you want to do

distracted driver, as an example. So all this intelligence
eventually kind of at the edge.

So what are you seeing in that space? And what kind of tools
are you seeing customers use? A really cool example that we
showcased at CES this past January,

and also at re:Invent, where
we talked about what Denso is doing.

They're building their next generation
edge hardware and software component

called their Mobility IoT Core. And in this they're looking
at technologies like Greengrass

and machine learning inference, where they're taking partner
applications from the insurance company

and deploying object detection algorithm in the vehicle so that they
can detect things like rolling stops

or combining it with canned data. And they have this
concept of video events,
they can capture the data coming from 6+ cameras in the vehicle

and stream that up to the cloud
using Kinesis Video Streams

to then connect those events that
you publish to the actual video stream. So you can now look at it after the fact
and share with your partners, and they can use it for other use cases. So that's an insurance example.

There's a lot of others
that you can begin to imagine. Awesome, awesome. I see in Twitch there's a comment about how
we can go into some of the code there.
So maybe what I'll do is I'll switch over. I had to go to my backup laptop.

So I'll actually be walking
through some of the architectures and where you get the code. So almost like Star Trek,
I'm going to the command center here over to my right. So I'll hop into this console.

If you want to take a look
at how this will be set up,

there's a link we'll post to Twitch so you can
take a look and see how this works. But to dive in a little bit more
about how the components come together,

you can do some of this at the edge. So there's a couple components
that you can end up running.

There's this concept of SageMaker Neo. So when we're talking about
how some of this runs at the edge,

you can think about
taking these precompiled models.

So, I apologize for the technical
difficulty, which was really funny, because it was kind of like, have you
ever been on one of those conference calls

where the other person
drops and you're like on a roll, and then you stop
and you realize you're alone?

That's about how I felt
walking through that example. So on this other laptop,
I was pointing out a few things to see.

So I mentioned KVS running
machine learning in the cloud,

based on image detection. So what I was showing is
you can get KVS set up pretty easily.

The way I actually like to do it
is you get two options. One, you can run it in Java.

We talked about Java. Am I still here too?
Has everyone still got me?
Yeah, you're there. OK, awesome. I'll take silence if I'm still on.

You're worried now
that it's going to end. Yeah, I know. I know.

But for the KVS side,
you can run it in Java, but I actually prefer
running it in Docker Container.

So what you'll end up
having to do is install ECR for a registry.

And then what will happen
is when you install it, you'll basically just pass over
information to connect to your camera.

So I can't run this live
because the camera is me. So that would be very strange.

But you can connect it over-- you can do Web RTC,
you can do RTSP streams,
you can do network-based IP cameras to pull the frame off of the data.

Before the actual image
detection, what I was showing is that when you launch
this CloudFormation template,

you'll basically pull in
a SageMaker Notebook to the tech images.

And a SageMaker Notebook looks like this. So within SageMaker,
what you're going to end up seeing,

is you'll end up seeing the ability
to pull the individual file images,

do the categorization of that image,
and then basically get an output.

So I was giving the analogy before that if I look away from the TV screen, you can get an idea
that you can no longer

really detect the front of my face, you can detect the side of it. So you can do things
like 'is this a face or not?'

'Is it someone is texting', so you
can see a phone in their hand? And those are things
that you can do in the cloud,

based on the image classification. You mentioned containers
as a great way to deploy an app,

especially for doing things at the edge, not just in the cloud,
like in your examples.

So we see automotive customers doing
a lot of work with containers at the edge. So that gives them a nice isolated
way to kind of distribute apps

down to their edge
clients running in the vehicle. And you can do that,
of course, with Greengrass.

When we post the links,
you'll be able to follow along. You can do things like the--
you mentioned Greengrass

with the ML in the containers. You can also do some
of the things kind of sidecar.

So you run SageMaker Neo, run Greengrass
separately with container support. So there's a fair amount
of options you get

as your choices in implementing Auto. It'd be great to maybe
dive into what you're seeing

in some of the provisioning in OTA cases. I know, Rudy,
that's a passion for you as well.

Yeah. I mean, in general,
with provisioning, it's such a, I'd say,
important part of infrastructure.

And most people kind of overlook it. So it's good that we've seen some
success with some of our customers,

especially with Automotive. So how are we applying some of
the best practices that we've learned for others, Dean?

Yeah. So we talked about
this solution a little bit earlier. We have a Connected Mobility Solution

with kind of our next generation
of the Connected Vehicle Solution that's already available on AWS.

And inside that solution,
we used a large component

from our Connected Devices Framework--
CDF, we call it. And what that has
is a whole section of code

and APIs all around provisioning. So with that framework,
we can very easily enable

a multi-tiered provisioning process,
where it gets elevated in privilege
when you go from one stage to the next. And an example would be

having a low-privilege certificate
after it gets burned in. And so when you're
manufacturing devices, you need to--

typically, if you're
not doing it in real time, I think a lot of times,
we both generate certificates,
create things offline, and then we

burn it all into the software. And then when we first key on
the vehicle at the manufacturing facility,

then we apply a low-privilege certificate
and kind of give it the ability to do some basic telemetry.

And then at the dealership
when you take ownership, we can use, say, a mobile app

and punch in a key, synchronize your
relationship to that vehicle,

and then give you full privileges. So all of that's supported
in the Connected Mobility Solution.

and you can customize that to your needs. OK, and you mentioned
the CDF, or Connected Device Framework.

Can you go into that a bit more? Absolutely. Yeah, the Connected
Device Framework is the foundation

upon which we've built
our Connected Mobility Solution that should be available within the
next month or so on our solution site.

And what we did was
we took all of the experience from hundreds of our
Professional Services engagements

and built this framework
called the Connected Device Framework. And in it we support a very flexible
elevated provisioning process,

where you can support the burn-in
of the software and the certificates

that allow it to connect
to the IoT framework, IoT core. And we can do
whitelisting, bulk provisioning.

And then once we have the device, the telematics control
unit's kind of ready to go.

They get assembled in the vehicles. And then when the vehicle
rolls off the assembly line,

on key on, the first key on, we
then assign a low-privilege certificate and we give it a policy.

And from there, it might be in transport
mode until you get to the dealership. And then the vehicle gets sold.

And we'll then elevate--
give it full privileges for all the telemetry and being
able to send commands  to the vehicle.

And so it's in use by
a number of customers

in heavy equipment
manufacturing and some others, and working with customers
today in Automotive on this.

So it's pretty flexible. OK, and you say you've
got the limited privileges,

then when you actually
purchase the car, it gets elevated. Is there ever a case where you might
want to remove some of the privileges?

Of course. Yeah. So yeah, you'll be
able to deactivate particular vehicles
if there's a threat of any kind. And then when we identify problems--

we spoke a lot earlier
about software recalls and the value of over-the-air updates.

So we use IoT jobs
to schedule over-the-air updates.

And we can do this from the Fleet Manager UI
that we talked about a minute ago.

So all that data that's coming through, and, like you mentioned,
there's a data lake.

and you want to analyze everything
so you can improve systems and continuously do that.

Is there in-vehicle telemetry
that's coming through, or do you have any anomaly detection?

Can you kind of get info that a bit? Sure thing. So we have a number of
different use cases that we support

in the Connected Mobility Solution. So we do things like
just secure data offload,

so getting that whole telemetry stream, goes into IoT core,
and then we use Kinesis Firehose
to drop it into S3, of course, which we discussed as being the heart of--

the heart of anything that runs on AWS. - Can't dodge it. Yeah. And then you build
your data lake on top of that.
Secondly, on that same stream, we can build a Kinesis Data Analytics application,

where you look at
anomalies from the data, and then you can start to build
vehicle health reports, things like that.

We also surface DTCs,
which is the Diagnostic Trouble Code.

So when your vehicle
fires off a lot of DTCs, when those take place,

we stream those, and
then we write them to Dynamo, we send them notification message to
trigger some kind of downstream process,

and even geofencing. So you can start to do
some geospatial use cases.

If your vehicle enters
a particular location, we can kick off an event
that could be any number of things.

So you're saying if I'm
going to go get some ice cream and I end up going to the ice cream shop,
that they'll just be like, 'Rudy, you've arrived! Here's your ice cream.'

Exactly. Yeah.
So they can say, like, 'Dean gained all this weight
during the COVID-19 crisis

because he was eating
gallons of ice cream.' So whenever I go by the grocery store,
I'll get an offer that'll say, 'Hey, come on in and get that special.'

So yeah, a number of use cases
around sending offers. But even like, you know, there are
public safety-related use cases

related to approaching
different areas for, say, extreme weather events

or chemical spills--a train goes
off the rails or something like that. We've seen a number
of those kinds of examples.

And many customers have
used their telemetry system

to give the location of vehicles to the government in crises
related to weather for safety concerns.

OK, cool, man.
I mean, it's fantastic to hear that there's all these
use cases that are possible.

And who knows the ones
we haven't heard yet? People are still inventing it. They just keep going.

But when you're storing it,
also, with the data, do you have an example?
I mean, is there any kind of demo you can take us through?

Yeah. So we can
spin up the solution right here.

So here's a quick clip
of us filtering some vehicles. So we've got our connected fleet live,
and there's some vehicles moving around. And we're kind of zooming in on them,

getting down to a collection of vehicles. And as you zoom in, the list on the right
will get smaller as you approach.

So then here's an example of a vehicle . When we click on it,
you can see some basic telemetry.

You can see the trip record. So here's the latest trip,
and we'll draw that route
and give you some elapsed time, 'How many miles?', for example.

And then we have this concept of video
events that we talked about earlier, where a video event was thrown off

where there was motion
outside your parked vehicle. And then we're going to
show here the video clip

that was captured from the vehicle from the cameras in the car. So it's pretty cool
to think that you can do this.

We were really happy to
showcase that at re:Invent with our partner Denso.

So that's just an example of the solution. And here, we talked
about anomalies and DTCs,

where we've got a problem
that's software related. So we're going to identify all
those vehicles that have those problems.

We'll zoom in on the Las Vegas area. And these are the vehicles
now that we want to implement

an over-the-air update for, for example. So just showing different
ways that you can filter
and refine that list on the right. So we'll go through it all.

And now we'll clear it out,
and we'll actually show how we can deploy an update.

Let's take a look at this one. We're going to schedule an update, and we'll grab the software
bundle for those vehicles,

and then we'll deploy it. And then this is all enabled
by the Connected Device Framework, which will kick off a
collection of IoT jobs.

And then you can monitor
the status of those updates. And the software in the vehicle
will then determine, OK,

when it's safe to apply those updates,
and that can be offline. Now, clearly, we know that
customers are using partners

to do sophisticated
over-the-air updates solutions. But in the case of micro-mobility

or where you've got aftermarket devices
you've deployed in your fleet, where maybe you want to take control

over the update of those bundles. You can use our framework in the
Connected Mobility Solution to do that.

So it's just kind of a good
starting point and reference for you to kind of implement
your custom solution.

That's one of the things that's
so exciting about joining AWS, was the continuous
innovation that, you know,
with all these new services coming out and new features for them,

it is a challenge,
but that's kind of where the hunger to learn something new

really helps you stay aware
of all the new capabilities.

So take advantage of your
Solution Architects from AWS to learn new stuff.

Ask for immersion days,
where you can dive deep and get your hands on code. Lots of resources on our site
for you to discover the new capabilities. Yeah. And to kind of add on to that,

I got to give a shout out
to Training and Certification. They've got lots of videos
that you guys can watch.

You might even see myself,
Wale, and Dean in those videos. So if you don't get enough
of a dose of us now,

you can kind of go to
Training and Certification, check it out there, aws.training,

and it's just a fantastic way
to get started with videos. From there, if you want
to go to the documentation,

you can go further. But it's a nice entry point
if you want these byte-size chunks

or if you want to think of it
as snackable learning. If there's no more questions-- let's see, any more questions?
Oh, wait.

I'll connect-- oh, wait.
Has connected-- How are connected vehicles
related with smart cities?

I think that's one for you. What? Yeah. So the connected vehicles
actually have a significant role to play
with a smart city. As cities start to instrument,

we're kind of monitoring the evolution of Vehicle-to-Vehicle,
Vehicle-to-Infrastructure technologies.

And I think we'll see
a lot more on this, with 5G, and Mac applications,

and the Cellular Vehicle-to-Everything
standards that are emerging. So this will help us coordinate traffic.

It will help autonomous vehicles
and vehicles with ADAS technologies

understand what's coming
around the corner that you can't see. So this is an emerging space,
and stay tuned.

So we'll talk a little bit how
AWS Wavelength kind of fits into that,

along with the Cellular
Vehicle-to-Everything. Again, thanks, everybody, for tuning in.

Dean, it was awesome having you. So through the challenges,
hopefully you learned a lot about All Things Mobility.

I'm Wale, again,
Worldwide Technical Lead for IoT.

And I'm Rudy.
I am a Senior Solutions Architect. We're joined by Dean Phillips today.

Say bye, Dean. Take care, everybody.
Enjoyed having the experience today.

This has been another episode of--
let's do it, boys. 'IoT All theThings.'
Oh, OK.
